Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: As the family holiday draws near, my phone buzzes with messages from my children and grandchildren, all eager to finalize our plans. They expect me to be there, to laugh and share stories, to keep our tradition alive. I know how much it means to them, especially since we haven’t all been together in so long. At the same time, I glance at the church bulletin on my kitchen table, reminding me of the special service this Sunday. My pastor has asked for volunteers, and I’ve always believed in being present, not just for worship but for the community that has become my second family. My heart aches as I think about missing either gathering. I want to be the grandmother who never misses a moment, but I also want to be the Christian who honors her commitments. The weight of these expectations presses on me, and I find myself torn, wondering how I can possibly choose between them.
